sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: My dear child, who could think of seeing you down here, (he turns from her, and walks.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Any business with me, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Why, my dear! Don't you know me, Natty?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Zounds, Ma'am, don't Natty me!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Won't you speak to your mother?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Who are you talking to, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Look at me—my own child deny me, (puts her handkerchief to her eyes, and walks up.)

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: John, is that the young man you saw?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: (Looking at his watch.) I shall be late with my party, (going.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Stay, my dear boy!

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: I'm nobody's boy, but my own man, he! he!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Seize him, (to John) Your name? (to Maggs.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: What of it?

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: What it was yesterday, and will be to-morrow.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Mind how he shuffles; do ye see it, John? Tell me your name to-morrow, (to Maggs.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Musn't, because of mamma. (aside.)

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: You belong to Mr. Pranks.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Supposing so.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Then I suppose you're my prisoner.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Me! for what!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: You broke out of jail in Babylon, but we'll handcuff and send you to Dorchester.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: (Aside.) Handcuff! Broke jail in Babylon! Ay! why surely they take me for Tom Pranks!—I'm not the person you want.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: I arrest you.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: I'm not the man indeed, my friend.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Who answers for you? who knows you?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Then I must own mother—let me go, this gentlewoman here is my honour'd mamma.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: (Aside.) A wicked wretch, first to deny, and now to own me in his distress!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Mrs. Maggs, be he your son?

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Oh! no, he's no son of mine.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Nay, my dear mamma.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Sir, don't mamma me; who are you talking to? (mimicking.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Ay! why sure, sweet mamma!—

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Stop; you see, my friend, it won't pass. John, look he don't run away, while I read discription of his parson, (takes out paper and reads) five feet eight inches tall, an expressive eye, pleasing features, good complexion, fine teeth, shew your teeth, (to Maggs) a handsome countenance—

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: 'Pon my soul this description's very much like me tho'.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Well-made, a genteel deportment; upon the whole, an elegant figure.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Amazing! what a picture of me!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Astonishing like the child indeed.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: You see it's you.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: No, it's such another handsome fellow, but really not me.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Come, I arrest you with a little tap, (trips up his heels) hold his legs, Jahn, that he mayn't kick I.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Damn'd uncivil this!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: I can't bear to see him treated so—let the child go, you fellows!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Yes, the child shall go—to prison.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: You're wrong, he's my son.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: And just now you said—Ay, I see how 'tis, Measter Butler told me that Mrs. Maggs locks herself in her own room, and there drinks the presarved apricocks—Jahn don't mind, Madam Maggs is so fond of talking she'll say any thing—bring him along.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Sir, gentlemen constables! mamma! kind country justices! mother! (Toby holding him by the head, and John by the legs, they drag him off.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Why, you horrid villains, you shall not!—my child!

div3.head: SCENE III. The Gardens. Statues thrown down, and broken fragments lying about; shrubs and plants, as pulled up.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p:
I vill complete the good work; lay there accursed, (throws it down on a heap) and I vill pulls
up thy groves, and I vill root thee out of the land, (pulls plants out of pots, and flings them about.)

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Sir, your dinner's waiting. (Aside) Dang my buttons! here's a fine kick-up! what rascal cou'd have got in here—some one that owes the 'squire a grudge.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: I've been doing of the job, 'twas all pagan wanity.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: So it was, Sir, and you were right to capsize it.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh! father, I shall go distracted; I'm sure it's my belov'd Tom that they're taking pris'ner to Dorchester, yet so cruel not to let me see him.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: I've left the prisoner in safe custody with Jahn Grum.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: (Aside.) Then I brings him up to town, and lodges him with the Marshal.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh heaven! tell me, Toby, is it the hermit?

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: It is he.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: 'Tis not tho'—why you're as bad as Mrs. Maggs, who just now said he was her son, and he wasn't her son—there's discription of his person, (gives Kitty a a paper.)

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: (Reading with emotion.) Handsome, elegant, fine teeth, expressive eye—'tis he! you hard-hearted creature—but I'll release my own true love, tho' I beg my bread for it.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Ay now, she too has been drinking apricocks.—Be's I to lay the cloth for you in the two-bedded room, (to Barebones.)

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: I loves to eat in a parlour.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Why we wish to resarve that for—

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Parlour! than, Sir, shan't I tap no vind—he won't inform— (to Barleycorn.)

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: I drinks vind, for I thirsts after the good things of this world.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: He's a wet Christian.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Shall they take up dinner?

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: Yes, I hungers after good; I could munch one morcil of Portlin mutton; yea, one pound and an half, and six, and four, and two wheat ears, roasted in wine leaves, and other settries of niceish saver.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: (Looking out.) The 'squire—dang my buttons, here'll be work.

div3.stage: Enter WHIMMY, (looks at the broken Statues with amazement.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Fury and distraction! what's all here!—Tully! (calls.)

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.l: "They'd be like the Highlanders eating of kall,

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: This is your going to the alehouse, here's your brags, here's yellow-breech'd bees humming their bag-pipes—but I'll turn over a new leaf, I'll dig and root out—

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p:
Arrah, Sir, I wish you'd let the leaves and the trees alone! you've been digging and rooting prettily:
what put it into your head to pull up the plants in this manner?

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: My head, there's my dancing Faunus.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: Oh! I see how this is; you want to keep me only as your show-man, and take the head gard'ning into your own hands—the geranums all torn, the myrtles, and lillies, and laylocks, are all pull'd about as if they were old bean stalks.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: You rascal! what do you talk of your paltry plants—look at my statues, none equal to them in the Barbarini gallery.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: The barber's gallery! Only tell a body what you intend to put down in the place—if yourself was planted, the devil a thing would grow out of your head but potatoe apples.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Two of my Seasons—

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: You don't know the seasons; you're a gentleman, and you've money to buy roots and fruits, but I tell you, you don't know an annual from an evergreen. I got myself finely laughed at to-day by showing your kickshaws, but I wash my hands out of it. There's your describing book (throws book down) and you may get another Ciceroni magpye to chatter to the company.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: There's a villain!

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Knock people's hats off—can't think who the fellow was!—Dick, I'm on the spur to fetch my nephew from Weymouth; an idle scoundrel! what perplexities he has involved me in! Dolts to apprehend Natty Maggs for him; these country constables are so obstinate, won't even take my word: but what sort of wild people have you settled amongst here that pull folks heads about?

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Yes, heads, legs, and arms, look! (points to the statues.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: (Looking round.) Ha! ha! ha! a good deed however.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: What, to demolish my beauties?

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Your modern gardens are art spoiling nature; fixing up a stone woman where one expects to find a rosy girl of health, flesh, and blood: if we must have statues, instead of importing ancient heathen gods into English meadow, why not encourage British arts to celebrate British heroes? for a Jupiter by Phidias give me an Elliot by a Bacon: the five thousand pounds you laid out upon that clumsy Pantheon yonder, wou'd have built a neat cluster of alms-houses, where age and infancy might find an asylum from the pangs of indigence.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Why, but Billy—

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: 'Sblood, when I reflect I owe my present independence to my education in the Blue Coat School, as I drive my whisky on a Sunday by Dulwich College, I feel more warmth of affection for the memory of Edward the king, or Alleyn the player, than for all the travelling cognoscenti in Christendom. Dick, I love reason.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: A rare chace, but I got from him—zounds! (sees Old Pranks, runs off.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Oh, damme, I'll have you, (pursues.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: He likes reason, and the fellow's mad; there he runs after my hermit. Certainly 'twas this savage old Goth committed these barbarisms—I hope he'll not find his nephew; however, I must prepare my daughter for the marriage.

div3.head: SCENE III. Inside of Hermitage. YOUNG PRANKS sitting in his Hermit's Dress, as if put on hastily.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p:
(Looking about.) I thought I had a glimpse of him darting this way—Eh! one of Whimmy's toys
— (seeing Young Prauks) Father Dominick—seen a scoundrel run in here—Do ye hear! can you speak!—it was certainly my nephew; a hound! skulking about, and suffer a poor innocent man to be taken up for him; to be handcuff'd, haul'd, and dragg'd—

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: An innocent man suffer for me! (throws off his hermit's dress.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: You! Oh you villain! How dare you borrow money about as you have done!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Sir, (confused) I—I—borrow'd money to get out of debt.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Eh! how?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, to pay my debts.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: But why get in debt?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: All owing to my good principle, the people wou'd trust me, my character was so excellent.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Then from your excellent character they think you a damn'd rogue—you villain!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p:
Dear Sir, discriminate between vice and folly; you are the only one I ever wrong'd, my second
parent, my friend, my benefactor. Sooner than let this person you spoke of just now any longer bear the disgrace that I only deserve, I'll instantly free him by delivering myself up to hopeless imprisonment, (going.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Eh! stop you rogue you, consider how terrible a prison is.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, no! the only difference between the people walking by and I is, that they're on one side of the door and I'm on t'other. A prison! to resign myself to it, now, is barely performing the duties of honesty.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Surrenders to free the guiltless! Not so bad as I thought him.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Sir, I've been told, since you're a banker gentleman in Lombard-street, London, you bankers, Sir, have always a great deal of money.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: (Aside.) I've heard of petticoat pads—a pistol may come out here! Well, my dear, granting I have money, do you want any?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p:
Not myself, Sir; there's a young gentleman is taken up for debt, Sir; I thought it a pity he should go to prison, as he got out of it before, and
that, you know, Sir, is a sign he doesn't like it; hard for a person to go where they can't be happy.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Upon my word this young lady reasons exceeding pretty—Well, Miss?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: And Sir, my aunt by mother's side, has left me three hundred pounds independent of my father, here are the papers, Sir, all about it, Sir, if you'd be so kind as to advance the money, and transact the business of releasing the young gentleman with it, I'd be very much obliged to you, Sir, (curtsies.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Here's a charming girl! And so, my dear, you think Natty Maggs so fine a fellow, that you give up all your fortune to release him.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Natty Maggs! No, Sir, our 'squire's hermit.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Hermit! She must mean my wild nephew, (overjoyed.)

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Sir, keep the papers, I know you'll free him; you look so good-natured, I beseech you, Sir, Sir,

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p:
Tol lol lol, (sings.) The heart of an amiable woman is the true touchstone of manly merit. This good and delicate creature loves my nephew, and he must be a worthy lad. The girl, no matter for
her situation, is come of a good stock, and should be transplanted. I didn't, till now, know my nephew—I'll forgive, I'll give him all—Go to the King's Bench again! that he shan't, while I've a guinea to keep him out of it, tol lol lol. Sings and exit.

div3.head: SCENE IV. A Gallery in Whimmy's House.
div3.stage: Enter YOUNG PRANKS (hastily crossing) and PEREGRINE meeting, (much agitated.)

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Stop, Tom, whither now?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: To the King's Bench—what's the matter? Oh, true, Miss Dian told me—upon my soul her father uses you both very ill—who is this whelp he is going to give her to?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: I don't know; Mr. Whimmy has never even seen him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: No! An uncle, isn't it that's bringing this about? I've a good uncle—but long before he'd think of providing me with an heiress—but then I've been such a cursed fellow.

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p:
One chance, this spark may, as it's a forced thing, be indifferent, and the old gentleman doats so upon
his daughter, that were an emperor to slight her, 'twou'd for ever lose his favour.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: What's this uncle's name?—who, where, what is he?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: I know nothing about him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Nor old Whimmy neither.

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: I've never seen him, I told you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Then I'll personate him, and I warrant you disgust the old gentleman sufficiently to make him break off the match; then, Peregrine, is your harvest, I'll be with you in a trice. Never be dismay'd, Peregrine, when you admit me as a schemer into your cabinet; for I have turn'd my coat so often since I arriv'd in these parts, that there is no doubt of my being a most finished politician.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: In vain talking, child;—I must keep my first promise.

sp.speaker: DIAN.
sp.p: But, dear Sir, will you sentence your child to misery?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Sir, you encourag'd me with a certainty that I shou'd be the happiest of men, and now in a moment, to snatch me from Heaven, and plunge me into an abyss of despair.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Can't help it, Dian;—I must give you to my friend's nephew.

sp.speaker: SKIP.
sp.p: Sir, here's a young gentleman will see you—seems in a piteous taking. Here's my master, Sir.

div3.stage: Enter YOUNG PRANKS, disguised like a boy, his hair pulled round his face, &c.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS,
sp.p: Oh! I will not have her.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Ah! who are you?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Certainly Tom Pranks. (To Dian.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: I don't want a wife. (Roars out crying.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Who the devil cares, whether you do or no—have you any business?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: No; I'm a gentleman. My uncle says I must marry your daughter; but I won't. (Roaring out.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Ah! can this be the wild rogue I've heard so much of? why, your uncle told me you were another-guess being. Dian, this is your husband.—How do you like him?

sp.speaker: DIAN,
sp.p: I fee this. Sir, if Mr. Peregrine can pardon me, since you've set your heart on't, I'm resign'd to your will, with the dutiful obedience of a daughter.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Now, that's very lucky. Peregrine, you see—

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Then, Sir, since the lady is so very fickle, I resign her with little regret.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Ah! this is all very well; then we'll call your uncle; Parson Jack is in the next room, and you shall be married immediately.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: But I won't marry, oh! (cries)—I'll never say, father-in-law, to such an ugly old fellow as you.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Why, you damn'd impudent young scoundrel, dare you affront me, and refuse my daughter? then let your uncle do his worst. There, Peregrine, take Dian, and may I be curs'd if ever I again attempt to part you.

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: You'll alter your mind again, Sir.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: I'll put that out of my power—go, Doctor, (calling off) tack that couple together instantly.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: My uncle! oh! zounds!

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Billy, what bouncing you've kept about this nephew of your's. He, a buck, and a blood!—a blubbering milksop.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: My Tom a milksop! I say he's a buck.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: I say he's an ass. (Wrangling, Y. Pranks cries out.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: There's the buck! a tasteless hound, has been abusing me here, and refused my daughter.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Oh! the devil! am I really the character I only personated. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Can't you see? thrash him for his impudence to me.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Why, ah, Tom!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Aye, poor Tom! (Snivelling.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: By the Lord, it's my galloping hermit! (surpris'd) and your nephew.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Sir, I now see your goodness; but had I even before known it, I cou'd not have enjoy'd the blessing you design'd for me, at the expence of a friend's happiness. Mr. Peregrine has love and merit.—I admire, but don't deserve the lady.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Then, since you're so disinterested as to decline the golden pippin, I'll give you a sweet wild strawberry.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: O Mr. Banker, have you—'tis he (looking at Young Pranks with joy) thanky, Sir. (Curtsies to Old Pranks.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Tom, here's a girl that wou'd have barter'd all her little fortune for your freedom; and now as you hope for mine, take her.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Why, she's daughter to the Red Lion.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Aye, my honest landlord, that reliev'd the sufferers, while you were swallowing peaches in December, and the poor shivering in cold and nakedness. Red Lion, Dick! where honour's derived from benevolence; she's daughter to a nobleman. What say you, my girl?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Only, Sir, that my heart is fill'd with gratitude; but you must ask the Red Lion's consent; for tho' you were a husband for a queen, I wou'd not have a prince, if it might grieve an indulgent parent.

div3.stage: Enter TOBY and JOHN GRUM, with MAGGS, (his dress very much disordered and torn.)

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Your worship, here's the defender is obstropolos, and has lick'd I and John Grum.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Aye, dem'me, I plump'd 'em.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Was't you, Natty? I'm sorry that my irregularities shou'd have involv'd you in this trouble.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Oh! Natty Maggs—my child to be haul'd and maul'd—but this comes of your denying me your honour'd mother.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Haul'd and maul'd—may the son never get better usage who cou'd deny his parent.

div3.stage: Enter BARLEYCORN and TULLY, bringing in BAREBONES.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Dang my buttons, you shall—

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: Only this devout preacher walks into Mr. Barleycorn's and crams himself like a great fowl; then walks off without discharging his shot; when ask'd, says he, you'll be paid above, and says Mr. Barleycorn, by who there? and says he, why by Abdiel; so they walk'd up stairs to me, where I was taking a pint and a whiff of tobacco. I was christen'd Mr. Tully, so I walks down—but who ever saw an angel with a pipe in his mouth? I don't mind paying for a man's dinner; but, Sir, be so kind as to send this geatleman to jall. How do ye do, Mrs. Maggs?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: My Saint George's Fields landlord!

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: The spirit openeth my mouth.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: You opened your mouth to swallow a leg of lamb, honey.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: All things shall be in common with the righteous?

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Pay me for sarving capias on Muster Pranks.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Me! how?

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Capias! What, you villain, are you that Ham Barebones that has lent my nephew money at an exorbitant usance.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: That, like the devil, tempted me by the means, and now punishes me for the sin.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: Talk of righteousness! and bilk the house of an honest industrious man. (Lays hold on Barebones.)

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Mrs. Peregrine (to Whimmy.)

sp.speaker: DIAN.
sp.p: Dearest father, your blessing. (They kneel to Whimmy.)

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: There, my blessing on you both, you two souls. (Puts his hand on their heads.)

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Then, my dear uncle, I take my lovely Kitty Barleycorn, and whilst her gentle qualities convince our friends, that birth and rank are not necessary to constitute an amiable wife, my respect for her virtues may prove, that the thoughtless prodigal can make a good husband.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Oh! I'm happy! ha! ha! ha! We've all got so very generous. Peregrine, with his little fortune, have Dian and all my wealth; your nephew, with your riches, takes little Kitty Barleycorn with nothing at all; and ecod, Mrs. Maggs looks so spruce, that I could find in my heart to— (going up to her.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Now that's so like Mr. Olmondle, (smiling and advancing.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Oh! (runs from her.)

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: And now, Mrs. Maggs, you will be drinking the apricocks.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Then, Sir, shall we be merry. Here ends my seven years hermitage, and, instead of my annuity, I shall think myself nobly rewarded, if my extravagant tricks and fancies can, by an indulgent smile, receive the forgiveness of my generous friends.
